text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text at the top of the left page, leaving the remainder for a full-page figural scene; the right page is dedicated to a schematic map-like illustration. Wide outer margins with stylized trees frame the composition.

text_content.script_style: Gothic cursive documentary hand with rapid strokes, moderate use of ligatures and abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Red is used prominently for garments and foliage accents, green for landscape and tree canopies, brown for ground and trunks, black for contour lines. The limited palette yields clear visual contrasts without shading; pigments are well preserved with minor fading in green areas.

features: Five figures clustered around a central pilgrim holding a cross-tipped staff
Stylized trees at left margin echo the verticality of the staff
Ground indicated by a single horizontal wash

decorative_elements: Map elements on right page: small buildings and tufts of vegetation
Red vegetal tufts repeated as border ornament

drawing_technique.line_style: Bold, uniform black-ink outlines executed with a quill
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color washes applied within contours, no gradation or hatching
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Flat spatial treatment, no attempt at linear perspective; overlapping figures indicate relative position

content_theme.scene_description: A single narrative scene occupies the left page: five male figures stand on a green-brown wash ground. At center right, a pilgrim wearing a patterned tunic and red hose holds a long staff topped with a small crossbeam. Four companions, clad in plain tunics and chaperons of red and brown, cluster to his left, two gesturing towards him. All wear pointed poulaines and belted garments; the pilgrim’s tunic displays a wavy pattern in red on a light ground. Two stylized trees with red-dotted foliage rise behind the group at left margin. The right page contains a schematic map: an ochre-green field bordered by tufts of red vegetation and small house-shaped buildings. No architectural framing is used in the main scene; the map’s organic border echoes the trees on the figure page. The Latin caption above directly refers to the pilgrimage episode, integrating text and image by thematic correspondence.

religious: Pilgrim holding cross-tipped staff, wearing patterned tunic
secular: Four male companions in chaperons and tunics, pointed shoes

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform thickness; skin side prepared by careful scraping and pumicing; ruling visible under UV as fine plummet lines.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall good: pigments stable with minimal flaking, slight discoloration of green washes, minor cockling at fore-edges.
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing in brown ink beneath figure contours
No raised gesso; color applied directly over primer

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Clerical or lay reader interested in travel accounts and map reading

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-15th-century manuscript leaf appears to originate from a regional workshop producing illustrated travel narratives or pilgrimage guides. The pairing of a full-page figural scene with a schematic map reflects a didactic impulse: the image of the crowned pilgrim and his companions visually anchors the text at the head of the page, while the right-hand map-like diagram reinforces spatial orientation. The bold black outlines and flat color washes, limited to vermillion and olive green, adhere to a pragmatic aesthetic typical of provincial scriptoria rather than the polychromy of major urban centers. The Gothic cursive hand suggests rapid documentary copying—likely for use by clerics or educated lay travelers. Iconographically, the cross-tipped staff identifies the central figure as a pilgrim, while the companions signal communal devotion. The stylized trees and tufts connect the narrative and cartographic spaces, creating visual cohesion across the spread. Comparatively, this layout recalls English Channel School manuscripts in its combination of travelogue and map, though the restrained palette and documentary script align more closely with Germanic or Italian itineraries. The synthesis of image, text, and map anticipates later devotional atlases and illustrates the broader medieval interest in integrating narrative and geographic knowledge.
